author: @Nickle314
text: 1. Could you start with single digits first - learn those.  2. Then extend the model training it on 2 digits by 1 digit, 1 by 2 etc 3. Then 2 digit x 2 digit.   etc.   Do you need to keep in the simpler examples in the training sets as you progress to harder?   Sort of the way human's learn.

author: @JohnDupuyCOMO
text: A direction that would be interesting: humans are known for thinking in a linear fashion. We are good at estimating addition and multiplication. But we are really bad at "intuiting" exponential math. From an economics point of view, it is why we have a hard time grasping the effect of things such as Moore's law. We can do the math, but it doesn't "feel" right. So, does deep learning have such a problem? Can it learn simple x^y ?

text: I had felt that you  could have gone with larger than 512 node layers. I'm guessing that each node will end up representing one number and with lesser nodes, it could represent fewer unique numbers as features.
